ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Re: the work load. I have never been assigned so much reading in a class in my life. It was quite burdensome at times. That being said, the work load makes a certain sense to me. It is all too easy for courses at FES to be superficial, and not get into depth. This is not one of those courses. This is a deep course about theory.

Class was heavily theoretical and students ranged between advanced PhDs to undergrads. This made the conversation very inaccessible at times, but also a great challenge as well. Some additional framing and contextualizing of material would be helpful. Perhaps less readings would allow for more in depth discussion -- smaller class size might also be better to promote quality discussion.

I found it really helpful when Karen or the discussion leaders summarized the main points of the authorsat the beginning of the discussion. I always did the reading, but since they were complex texts, making sure I did understand them correctly was helpful.Karen is great, really so generous with her students and has such impressive knowledge/recall of so much literature. She was also very available to talk about term projects.

This class was extremely challenging for me. I learned a lot but it was not a fun experience. It was very difficult to follow the subject matter and I always felt I was lagging far behind and desperately trying to catch up, but could never quite get there. That being said, looking back the theory I learned was fundamental and very necessary and I don't know if I would have been able to get that kind of grasp elsewhere.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Getting a solid foundation in social theory.
Concepts were theoretical but extremely relevant for larger context of my work and studies. Class discussion was often at a very high level, so much to learn.

The reading choices were awesome and the course was great exposure to them. The weekly write-ups were challenging, but it did make me pay close attention to the readings (which I'm sure was the objective!). Being around really well-read, smart people (including Karen) was also really inspiring.
When I got it, it was fun.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Discussion could be facilitated better. People have amazing things to say, but for some reason there was an atmosphere of restraint.

More framing would be helpful in pulling together different aspects of the class. More structure on the reading responses would be useful to build analytical skills and set goals to improve throughout the class on writing.

Weekly readings need to be reduced in order to make the course manageable. A workload over-load often resulted in poor reading by the many class members which meant that conversations were easily dominated by a selective few who were already familiar with the material and, therefore, could get through it in its entirety.

I'd say that the role of the discussion leader wasn't as consistent from week to week as it might have been. It was great that people had freedom to try different approaches. But the amount of leeway they actually had kind of varied depending on whatever other topics, themes, or questions came up before they really got going. This occasionally seemed disappointing if the leaders didn't have time to get to everything they had planned.
It would be better if Karen did more to involve students that do have have such a background in the major theoretical texts.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: In terms of investigating how markets and market based solutions fit into advocacy, this course offers a great foundation of theory for understanding markets, and the marketization of nature/natural products.
Course strengthens theoretical understanding of economic development on a local and global scale. I wanted a better understanding of the structural roots of some of today's resource problems.
Super helpful in understanding the major theory but not in practical matters.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See above, q 17.
To gain background in theoretical underpinnings of economic development and alternative perspectives on the drivers of environmental degradation.
It sounded interesting.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes.

For the most part, yes. I wish there was additional emphasis on writing and analysis related to the texts. That would have been a concrete skill to develop throughout the class, but perhaps hard because of the varied skill levels in class.
Yes, I think so! But I suspect I'll have to continue to re-read some of these texts before I really have a solid handle on them.
I learned so much, but I felt very unprepared for the text and it was not a very pleasant experience.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be ready for a massive massive load of reading. Set aside the time, because the reading is worth it.

This is an advanced course, so prior knowledge in the subject area would be helpful. There is a lot of heavy reading so be prepared to devote time to getting through everything. Class challenges many of the base assumptions and thinking common to environmental management and is extremely helpful in thinking about the root causes of the problems many of us are trying to solve.
Be prepared for a lot of reading! But it's a great class.
It is A LOT of reading. LIKE RIDICULOUS. And the PhD students in the class will likely not help you feel all that welcome but it you will look back and realize that you have learned a lot.
